document.text: Zack Elliott Cheatham, 82, of Evergreen hid Tuesday, July 4,19TB in Medferi Care Center inIA 6 hhucg HI Bora in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late James Hudson, and MoUy Evans Chetttham. R t v u a farmer and dealer in cattle and horses and member of the Virginia Horse Show Association. He is survived by his wife, Mayme Chocklett Cheatham a son, James Elliott Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. a daughter, Jeanne C. Stanley of Appomat tox two sisters, Annie C. Bingham of Lynchburg and Alice C. Babcock of Columbia. S.C. four grandchildren, Zack and Nan Cheatham of Clear water, Fla., and Bill and Jan Stanley of Appomattox, and a great-grandson, James Hudson Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. Besides the immediate fam ily, there were present a niece, Mrs. Anne Branmgan. and husband from California a nephew. Cecil Robbins, and wife from Wilmington, N. O. and a nephew, Huck Babcock, from Columbia, S. C. and many cousins. Funeral services were con ducted at 130 p.m. Friday from Robinson Funeral Home m Appomattox. Burial was m Evergreen Cemetery. Serving as pall bearers were Jack Baker, David Paulette, Kermit Paulette, Edward Har vey, Leslie Goodrich, Jesse Franklin, Herbert Diadmond, and Henry Simmons.

document.text: y Brooklyn, N. Y .Preaching at the Irving Square Presbyterian Church on the theme, The Life Spiritual in Christ the Fundamental in Chris tianity, the Rev. Ira Wemmell Hen derson, pastor, took as his text John 35 Verily, verily, I say unto thee, except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God. He said It is my desire, as the Spirit may give me wisdom, to unfold to you what, to my mind, is the fundamental in Christianity. From the words of our Master I conceive the truth to be that, save as we apprehend the spiritual verities revealed in Jesus Christ save as -e see the world, man, our God, with the spiritual vis ion, we cannot become partakers of the glories of the kingdom of our Father. Only as we open our hearts and minds to the indwelling Spirit of Almighty God do we enter into the promised land of the new dispensa tion, to possess it, to enjoy it. Filled with the Spirit we, live, but if the Spirit of God abide not in a man he Is none of His. In that beautiful figure of the vine Christ cuts clear for us the nature of the spiritual life. It is our oneness within the Author of the universe and of us. It is the merging of our lives Into the life of God. The perfect spiritual life expresses itself in union within the Maker. Entirely within the lining Christ moves the flawless human. Fashion a man according to the stature of Jesus Christ and you have a spiritual man. The spiritual life is that life within Christ which will make you always ask, What would Jesus do? The ethical judg ment always referring for its sanction to the spiritual. Spirituality and godliness are syn onymous. Apart, from the glorified Nazarene there is, Christianly speak ing. no spiritual existence. Spiritual ity is no mere statement of philoso phy it is a fact. A vital and a vivi fying reality Is the life within the Son of Man. The Christ, life is not merely a state of mind, but a mode of action. The living of the man within Jesus and for the Father, and the Holy Spirit dwelling in him, that Is the life spiritual. As the late Or. plaltbie D. Babcock well said  Spir ituality is seeing God in common things and showing God in common things. Now this spiritual life is not eso teric in its nature. It Is not a life for the few. It is a life for us alt. The economy of the good news of the Master is worldwide in its application and inclusiveness. To all men the opportunity to dwell within Christ is offered. To ail the higher life has its appeal. From Nlcodemus of the San hedrim, to Oneslmua the slave. From the mighty in intellect, to the unlet tered and unlearned. To the banker, to the beggar, without money and Without price, are given all the wealth at Gods command if they will. The highest Christian life is in

document.text: Womans Club Lists Committee Heads In announcing committee heads for the Appomattox Womans Club for 1976-76 year, Mrs. H. Webster Babcock, president, reminds members that dues for the new year are payable to Mrs. Frank Chu- chek, treasurer. The call to the Board of Directors meeting, V.F.W.C., Ingleside, Staunton, Va., Sept. 10-11, 1975 is extended to our state, district officers and chairmeh, and local presidents. Department chairmen for the Appomattox Club are Mrs. Thomas Richardson, Home Life Mrs. Martin Webb, Education Mrs. Howlette Martin, fine arts Mrs. Harry Lawson, Public Affairs Mrs. Charles Guill, Child Welfare - Justice for Juverniles Mrs. Henry C. Moore, Conservation and Community Improvement. document.text: Womans Club held its January meeting Thursday at the home of Mrs. Joseph Dutka of Thomas Terrace. In December the members gave a Christmas party for the Spout Spring Home For the Aged. Christmas cards were given to all the patients, Christmas stocking were made, filled and given to all. Re freshment were served by Mrs. Eddie Gunter, Jr., Mrs. Clayton Stanley, and Mrs. Joseph Dutka. Christmas cards were also sent to the shut-ins in the Concord area. The clubs formal Christmas party for its members and their husbands was held at the home of Mrs. Laurel Stanley, Corresponding Secretary with Mrs. Marge Dutka, assisting her in the duties of hostess. It was decided that on Jan uary 29 and 30 the club members would be volunteers for the Bloodmobile visit that will be held at Babcock and Wilcoxs Mt. Athos Plant at that time. All that work at B  W are urged to sign up for donating their blood. A Fine Arts, including Art, Sculpture, and Photography, Handcraft, Literary including Essay, Short Story, One Act Play and Skits, and Poetry show will be sponsored February 6 in the Concord Elementary School. The public may exhibit and view all exhibits. A Square Dance will be held February 10 at Concord Elementary School with H. T. Nash Band furnishing the music. The proceeds will go toward Concord Community

document.text: William Edward Dickerson, 93, of Spout Spring, died Tues day at his hom e. He was the husband of the late Nannie Mor ris Dickerson. Born in Appomattox County, he was a son of Elijah Thomas Dickerson and Sallie Woodson Dickerson. He was a member of Salem United Methodist Church. He was a merchant in Spout Spring for 55 years. He is survived by three sons, Claude M. Dickerson of Spout Spring, Earl H. Dickerson of Lynchburg and W. E. Dickerson Jr. of Chatham six daughters, Mrs. H. B. Martin, Erna Dick erson of Spout Spring, Mrs. H. C. Babcock of Lynchburg, Mrs. E. W. Elkstrand of Alexandria, Mrs. E. H. Frazier of Altavista and Mrs. G. M. Turemau, Jr, of Richmond five sisters, Mrs. J. P. Scruggs of Elkton, Mrs. Mit- tie Wooldridge and Mrs. D. S. Evans of Lynchburg, Mrs. M.H. Jones of Princeton, W. Va.,and Mrs. E. H. Howerton of Logan, W. Va., 17 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be con ducted at 2 p.m. Thursday to-

document.text: William D. Ferguson William D. Ferguson, 32, an electrician employed by Babcock Wilcox in Lynchburg, died Thursday in Lynchburg General Hospital. Born in Appomattox County, tie was a long time conn ty resident and recently ihoyed to Rustburg. lie was a member of Lynchburgs National Guard Unit and the Central Baptist Church of Appomattox County. Surviving are Jus parents, Mr. and Mrs. Everett Ray Ferguson of Appomattox his wife, Mrs. Edith Pence Ferguson two sons William D. Ferguson, Jr. Thomas Ray Ferguson daughter, Miss Ouida Ann guson, all of Appomattox brother, Calvin Ray Ferguson, of Lynchburg two sisters, Mrs. J. L. Owen of Rustburg and Mrs. Paul Coleman of Lynchburg and a maternal grandfather, W. T. Nash of Appomattox. Funeral Services were conduct ed at 4 p.m. Saturday at Robin son Funeral Home by the Rev. Winfred Elder, the Rev. Joe R. Holland and the Rev. William F. Patrick. Burial was in Central Baptist Church Cemeetry. Pall bearers were Richard Nash, Er nest Hines, Roger Gaelick, E. W. Marshall Jr., J. P. Harvey, Jr., Frank Moore, Albert Harvey and Nelson Mann.

Air Force Cadet of Colorado, is spending three weeks with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Notestein.
